Award.AwardTitle: Quantifying How Bioenergetics and Foraging Determine Population Dynamics in Threatened Antarctic Albatrosses
Award.AbstractNarration:
Albatrosses (family Diomedeidae) are among the most threatened of bird species. Of the 22 species that are currently recognized, all are considered at least Threatened or Near-Threatened, and 9 are listed as Endangered or Critically Endangered. Because of the decline in albatross populations and the birds' role as a top predator in the pelagic ecosystem, it is vitally important to understand the factors affecting the population dynamics of these birds to better inform strategies for conservation and mitigating environmental change. The goal of this project is to answer the question: What are the population consequences of albatross bioenergetics and foraging strategies? The investigators will take a two pronged approach: 1) constructing, parameterizing, and validating an Individual Based Model (IBM) that rests on Dynamic Energy Budget theory and state dependent foraging theory; and 2) undertaking an in-depth meta-analysis of existing individual tracking and life history data from multiple albatross species across successive life stages. This theoretical work will be grounded with a unique and extensive data set on albatrosses provided by collaborator Richard Phillips from the British Antarctic Survey. The IBM approach will incorporate details such as adult energetic state, chick needs and energetics, reproductive stage, and spatial and temporal variation in prey availability within a single framework. This facilitates exploration of emergent patterns, allowing the investigators to explicitly link behavior, energetic, and population dynamics.

Bioenergetics constrain a variety of behaviors. A more complete understanding of how individuals use energy can give insight into how behaviors from foraging to breeding and survival, and resulting population attributes, might change with environmental factors, due to anthropogenic and other drivers. This work will further a general understanding of how bioenergetics shapes behavior and drives population level processes, while providing an approach that can be used to guide conservation strategies for endangered populations. The research findings and activities will be made accessible to public audiences through websites and on a blog maintained for the project by a postdoctoral researcher. The project will involve undergraduate and high school researchers in the project, within formal laboratory groups and also through in-classroom presentations and activities. This project also involves outreach to local elementary schools, as the albatross-Antarctic bioenergetics system provides a charismatic and tangible teaching tool, for exploring a complex conservation issue, and demonstrating the utility of quantitative biological research approaches. All project publications will be open access, the resulting open source software will be released to the public, and metadata and analyses will be fully documented and made available through the Knowledge Network for Biodiversity, to promote further collaborative exploration of this system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
All animals must successfully gather food in order to survive and reproduce. Therefore, understanding foraging behavior and how animals gather and use energy ("bioenergetics") is a major goal of behavioral ecology. Bioenergetics constrains behavior and life history from foraging to breeding and survival. Thus, a more complete understanding of how individuals use energy can give insight into how these behaviors and patterns, and resulting population attributes, might change with the environment, due to anthropogenic and other drivers. 

The overall goal of this project was to understand how behavior and bioenergetics interact in Antarctic albatrosses. Albatrosses (family Diomedeidae) are large, very long lived, and produce only a single egg either annually or biennially. They are among the most threatened of bird species: of the 22 albatross species recognized by the IUCN, all are Threatened or Near-Threatened, and 8 are Endangered or Critically Endangered. Due to declining populations, and their role as top predator in the pelagic ecosystem, it is vitally important to understand their population dynamics, to better inform strategies for conservation. We used a research sequence comprising data synthesis, modeling, and training, to link together what we know about foraging, movement, and bioenergetics in these birds. This grant provided opportunities for international collaboration, training the next generation of scientists, and advancing software in both data synthesis and modeling approaches. 

Through a collaboration with the British Antarctic Survey (BAS), we were able to access multiple sources of data derived from fieldwork (e.g., weights and lengths of growing chicks over time) and micro-logger foraging and activity data, for multiple albatross species, spanning almost 30 years. Annual trips to the UK during the US summer, to work directly with BAS collaborators while they were not conducting fieldwork, was fundamental to data identification and retrieval. During the data synthesis component, we encountered many informatics hurdles, such as outdated or even completely deprecated file types, inconsistent variable names, and reconciliation issues arising from changing data logger technology. Creating cleaned and aligned data was a key step in refining empirical information for intended modeling approaches. Additionally, generalizing techniques for harmonizing information from multiple logger types and generations led to development of open source software for the community to build on, as the technologies to measure and record empirical field data change.  

To characterize foraging behavior, the data loggers record when albatrosses are wet or dry, allowing us to define foraging "flights" as when the birds are not wet. These foraging trips are characterized as distributions of "jump lengths" (lengths of times when birds are dry). While characterizing these newly cleaned data, we discovered that previously reported patterns of jump lengths may be incorrect, due to problems with statistical approaches, and that the data resolution has an out-sized impact on what patterns can be inferred. We recommended alternative approaches to quantifying jump patterns to allow us to better understand jump data that has been collected across time at multiple resolutions.  

Next, we built models that explicitly describe how albatrosses use energy for their life processes. We built mathematical models known as Dynamic Energy Budget (DEB) models. These models are among the simplest that can describe the full life cycle of organisms, yet can allow extrapolation to a full life cycle based on juvenile data (our primary source of the detailed size and weight data necessary for bioenergetics models in general). DEB models are formulated as sets of differential equations fit to growth data (and reproduction data, if available). To fit these models, we first cleaned and aggregated albatross chick growth data. We also had considerable additional biological knowledge to use as prior information to constrain model parameters. Thus we wanted to use Bayesian statistics to fit the models in order to efficiently combine the growth data with prior knowledge. Since no off-the-shelf software existed to do this, we built a software package to fit the models in a Bayesian framework. We constructed a variety of simple DEB models and fit them to existing data as proof of concept and built software tutorials to allow others to use this approach. This software package has subsequently been used by other researchers to fit a variety of models, including for transmission of COVID-19. 

This grant allowed for intensive informatics and statistical training of a co-mentored postdoctoral researcher (PR) and a graduate student researcher (GSR). The PR accrued significant training in statistical methods, generally, and Bayesian methods, specifically. The PR also learned about developing scientific software in the R computing language. The PR is now a professional statistical ecologist with the British Trust for Ornithology. The GSR learned about how to fit complex biological models using Bayesian methods, and is currently completing his PhD in statistics using related approaches.
